text: hey guys welcome back thank you so much
for joining me for episode three of DIY
technical design in this episode we're
going to be talking all about size
charts and grading
all righty before we can move on to
creating our own size chart we first
need to identify what our customer body
type is are you dressing for someone
who's athletic someone who is younger
maybe a juniors or children style
determine what your ideal customer body
type is and then determine what your
ease over body is for your garment is
your garment going to be fitted or is it
going to be loose is it a body con dress
or is it a loose fitted sweatshirt for
young boys now that you've determined
your ideal customer body type and your
ease over body we can move into creating
our very own size chart your size chart
is where you're going to list out all of
the measurements that line up with your
size say your size chart has two main
functions to be used both publicly and
internally your public measurements that
you post on your website are for your
customers to identify what size they fit
within usually this is characterized by
four main measurements which are the
bust waist hip and height however if
you're creating something a little bit
more specific like bottoms you might
include the inseam as well
your internal size chart will have a lot
more measurements on it and will help to
guide you in creating your points of
measure so that all of your sizes are
consistent across styles the fashion
industry does not have any size
standards that's why often times you
will fit into multiple different sizes
across brands it's important to look at
the trends within the category that your
garment fits within and across your
competitors but you can also create the
sizes however you want
Lululemon is a great example of this
where they have created their very own
sizing and encourage your customers to
get educated about what that sizing
means and what sizing they fit into this
is a great way to build a customer base
and to build a community around your
brand because instead of having your
summers compare themselves to other
brands where they fit in a certain size
and being like why don't I fit in this
size in this brand they are able to just
remove themselves from thinking about
other brands and just focus on okay
what's my size in your brand to create
your size chart you'll first need to do
a little bit of research start by
compiling a list of all of the size
charts that you can find among your
competitors on their website find the
average of all of these competitors this
will give you a pretty good idea of what
the standard is among your ideal
customer body type you can also take a
look at what the measurements are for
standard fit forms in the industry just
do a google search or go to places like
the shop company and take a look at what
their size guide looks like comparing
the measurements from a fit form size
guide can give you a good idea of where
you may need to adjust your size chart
now that you have a good standard for
the industry trends you can start making
adjustments based on your ideal customer
body type make any small adjustments and
you can also take a look at real-life
fit models or even fit forms to compare
and contrast the numbers that you've
come up with and make any small
adjustments from there your size chart
can just be created as a basic table
using programs like Word Excel Photoshop
Illustrator those can all be great
options to add a little bit more
branding to it especially if you'll be
using it on your website
now that we've created in our size chart
we can move into grading grading is just
the difference between sizes in your
size charts so from small to extra small
is it a one inch difference two inch
difference that's what your grade is for
your public size chart it's going to be
a pretty consistent grade usually it's
like one inch or something along those
lines and it's just more simplified in
order for your customers to be able to
identify what size they fit into
however grading is a lot more
complicated than that and it can be
different between every single size it
can be really inconsistent and its style
and fabric specific it can get
especially complicated at the lower and
higher ends of the size chart because
the body doesn't grow consistently a
smaller waist size doesn't necessarily
mean a shorter height and vice versa so
to find your grade all you need to do is
find the difference between the sizes in
your size chart in order to create a
consistent grading method it you'll need
to learn a little bit more about the
trends for sizing there are companies
who are dedicated to that kind of
research which ASTM International is one
of them or you can do a little bit of
your own research again just looking at
other company's size charts or fit forms
life fit models those are all great ways
to determine what the grading trends are
for your specific industry keep in mind
that your size chart doesn't have to be
perfect right away
as you move through development or even
after you start selling get some
customer feedback get some fit feedback
from your fit models or other people on
your team ask a friend and you can
adjust your size chart from there so it
doesn't have to be a document that can't
be changed it can totally be adjusted as
you move through the development cycle
to make this a little bit easier you can
create a template that is style or
fabric specific you can see how I
implement this in Episode one the tech
Park tutorials that I show you can see
how I set up my points of measure so
that my grade is laid out and I can
compare it consistently across all of my
points and measure you can just copy
this same format and use it for
different fabric types or style types
for example you could do one for men's
knits and then one for men's outerwear
which would directly correlate to the
differences in the type of fabric I know
that this method takes a lot of research
a lot of time but doing all this work up
front to researcher competitors and
develop your science chart and figure
out what your greeting is is a really
good way to start out so that you have
consistent fit going forward if you want
to save some time and skip some of that
research I do have some standard size
chart templates available on my website
that do include the grade and I'll have
those linked below in the description as
always I have a full blog post that goes
into a little bit more detail I have an
additional section that has information
about fit models fit forms and blocks
and you can find that full blog post
linked below
all right guys that wraps it up for
today if you have any questions of
course leave a comment please like
